Heading: Raised by
Value: Adoptive parents – the Bianchis; Biological mother was a prostitute who gave him up for adoption at birth

Heading: Family event
Value: His adoptive father died of a heart attack. His adoptive mother, who he was very attached to, then had to start working to support the family.

Heading: Problems in school?
Value: By age eleven he was having furious tantrums during class.

Heading: Head injury?
Value: Age of 11- fell off of a jungle gym and hit his head.

Heading: Psychologically abused?
Value: There is a possibility that he was mentally abused, but there is no documentation of any certain event.

Heading: Father’s occupation
Value: Adoptive father was employed by the American Brake shoe factory.

Heading: Mother’s occupation
Value: Was employed, but her exact occupation is unknown

Heading: Mother abused drugs/alcohol
Value: Biological mother abused alcohol. No alcohol abuse reported for adoptive mother

Heading: Grades in school
Value: Teachers reported that he was working below his capacity

Heading: Applied for job as a cop?
Value: Yes, for a while he started taking classes to become a police officer but dropped out before finishing. He then applied for a job with a  Sheriff’s Department but was turned down.

Heading: Worked in law enforcement?
Value: Yes, held a position as a security guard

Heading: Fired from jobs?
Value: Yes, asked to leave after being found stealing, and fired from another job after marijuana was found in his desk.

Heading: Types of jobs worked
Value: He went through several jobs, one job he held was at a title company. He also prepared a fake diploma for himself and began to practice as a psychologist.

Heading: Marital status
Value: He had a common law wife and re-married while in prison

Heading: Bed wetting
Value: No, but he had bladder control problems.

Heading: Abused drugs?
Value: No, but was fired from a job when pot was found in his desk.

Heading: Been to a psychologist?
Value: Yes, mother sent him to one as a young boy.

Heading: Committed previous crimes?
Value: He was suspected in the Alphabet murders in New York, but his involvement was never confirmed

Heading: Killed prior to series? Age?
Value: Not positive, but yes, if he did commit the Alphabet murders

Heading: Number of victims
Value: 12 (the last two murders were carried out solely by Kenneth Bianchi, Angelo Buono was not involved with these)

Heading: Victim type
Value: Vulnerable young women (prostitutes, low-income, students, low scale models and actresses);  Also murdered two very young girls – ages 12 and 14

Heading: Killer age at start of series
Method of killing
Value: Strangulation, rape, various types of torture

Heading: Killing occurred in home of victim?
Killing occurred in home of killer?
Value: Possibly, evidence was found in Bianchi’s apartment

Heading: Weapon
Value: No weapons, as most of the murders were ruled as death by strangulation. However, various items were used to tie and bound the victims.

Heading: Tortured Victim?
Value: Yes, as the murders progressed the detectives investigating saw the Hillside Stranglers experimenting more and more with methods of torture.

Heading: Bound the victims?
Value: Yes, ligature marks on the victims hands and feet were the 'calling card' of the Hillside Stranglers.

Heading: Left at scene, no attempt to hide
Moved, no attempt to hide
Value: Yes – once murdered, the bodies were moved to remote locations near hillsides

Heading: Date convicted
Value: October 21, 1979. Sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

Heading: The Hillside Stranglers (videotape)  (1998).  Arts and Entertainment Television.
